Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Collaborative REU in Astronomy in Flagstaff, Arizona
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will fund the continuation of a productive REU program led by Dr. Eastwood at Northern Arizona University. The program will host seven students for ten weeks each summer and will offer the students research projects in a variety of disciplines. Projects will be available in astronomy, astrophysics, planetary science, and astrogeology. PhD mentors for the students will be recruited from various institutions in the Flagstaff area including Lowell, NAU, the US Naval Observatory, and the US Geological Survey. Although the students will spend most of their time working on their research projects, there will be ample opportunities for them to attend seminars given by the Flagstaff research community and to participate in field trips planned to various research sites. The stated objectives of this project are to provide the participants with a publishable research project, a supportive environment, explicit career mentoring, and colleagues for life.

The very nature of an REU site results in a broader impact, in terms of educational activities. As noted above, the programs stated goals include aspects of Broader Impact for the student participants including providing a supportive research environment and career counseling. This program has a particularly good post-participation tracking program. Of the 155 program alumni since 1991 58% are female and 26% of the alumni now hold PhD degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates summer program in astronomy at Northern Arizona University has been running continuously since 1991. Each year, seven or eight students were recruited nationally and placed with individual PhD mentors at NAU and the Lowell Observatory, and sometimes at the astrogeology branch of the U.S. Geological Survey or the Flagstaff station of the U.S. Naval Observatory. The students were housed together on campus, and received three hours of university credit. In addition to their research projects, the students participated in a series of scientific research talks and professional development seminars.  The range of research projects was fairly large, with an emphasis on planetary science and star/planet formation.

During the five summers of this award, there were 37 REU students; we hired two extra above the promised 35 using carryover from the previous award. The number of completed applications averaged around 140 every year, with a low of 120 in 2010 and a high of 166 in 2013. Of the 37 students, 22 (59%) were women, and five (14%) were Hispanic (two women and three men). Thirteen (35%) of the students were from primarily undergraduate institutions. Only three (8%) were from the home institution, NAU.

We have tracked the 193 students who participated in our program between 1991 and 2014. Of the 135 students who are not currently enrolled students (either undergraduate or graduate), we have lost track of only 8 (6%). Of the 135, 16 (12%) are tenure-track professors, and 15 (11%) are in other educational positions. 29 (21%) are researchers (postdoc or soft money or FFRDC), and 13 (10%) are in research support positions. 35 (26%) are working in industry in STEM fields. Only 18 (13%) work in non-STEM fields.

The intellectual merit of this award lies in the excellent research projects done by undergraduate students, many of them publishable. Typically most of the students present their work at a scientific conference with a published abstract, and some of those are also published in refereed journals. As the typical lag time for publication is typically two years, much of the work supported by this award has not yet been published.

The broader impact of this award lies in the development of a diverse, globally competitive workforce. As described above, the percentage of participants that are young women is not only above the national average for astronomy, but above their representation in the population. As demonstrated by our tracking, over 90% of the 185 participants for whom we have current tracking information are still engaged in STEM activities, either in research, education, or industry.
